title: Setting up an Approved Tachograph Centre (ATC)

details.description: How to set up an Approved Tachograph Centre (ATC), how much it costs and who you can employ

parts.title: How to apply
parts.body:
If you want to set up an Approved Tachograph Centre (ATC), you will need to read the ATC manual and fill in form GV07.

Download ‘ATC manual’ (PDF, 2.1MB)

Download ‘Form GV207’ (PDF, 60KB)

Send your application to the address on the form.

You can also contact the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) for the form and manual.

VOSA
Telephone: 0300 123 9000
Monday to Friday, 7:30am to 6pm

parts.title: Costs and equipment
parts.body:
It costs:

  • £361 to register as an Approved Tachograph Centre (ATC)
  • £148 to renew your registration each year

You can register to work on analogue tachographs, digital tachographs, or both.

Equipment

The ATC manual tells you what equipment you’ll need to buy.

Download ‘ATC manual’ (PDF, 2.1MB)

parts.title: Who can work for you
parts.body:
You can only employ ‘nominated technicians’ to carry out work at an Approved Tachograph Centre (ATC). They must be skilled technicians with experience working on tachographs.

If they need to road test vehicles, they must also have a driving licence for the relevant categories of vehicles they’re testing.

They’ll also need to hold a ‘certificate of competence’ for each class of tachograph (digital, analogue or both) that they want to work on.

They’ll get this only after they’ve successfully completed a Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA)-approved training course. You’ll find details in the ATC manual.

Download ‘ATC manual’ (PDF, 2.1MB)

parts.title: Tachograph workshop smart cards
parts.body:
A tachograph workshop card is used to calibrate digital tachographs. To be eligible for a workshop card, you must:

  • be a nominated technician working at an Approved Tachograph Centre (ATC) with digital status
  • hold a digital training certificate

Tachograph workshop cards are issued free of charge. They must be renewed every year on 31 March.

The cards are issued to a nominated technician, not to a centre - this means that only the individual who has the card can use it.

If you’re the nominated technician and you work at 2 workshops, you’ll need a card for each workshop.

How to apply

Fill out an application form D778B and send it to the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA), where your application will be checked and approved. It will then be forwarded to the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA), who will issue your card to the ATC where you work.

You’ll need a PIN code to use a workshop card. This will be sent to your home address, and must only be used by you.

Download ‘D778B: Application for a digital tachograph workshop card’ (PDF, 372KB)

Before you fill in the application form, read ‘How to fill in your application for a digital tachograph workshop card (D778B)’.

Download ‘How to fill in your application for a digital tachograph workshop card (D778B)’ (PDF, 211KB)

For more help, contact the VOSA helpline.

VOSA helpline
0300 123 9000

Working with tachograph workshop cards

Workshop cards can hold:

  • details of 88 calibrations
  • a small amount of events and faults data

Cards should be used as a driver card during any road tests related to tachograph work. This means that calibration details, periodic inspection details and any subsequent road test can be recorded together and downloaded to give a complete record of each vehicle’s activities.

A workshop card must not be used instead of a company card. If you have a card used by your calibration centre, this must only be used in accordance with the tachograph centre’s duties and not as a substitute company card.

All insertions of a card are recorded on the vehicle unit and the card.

Renewal of workshop cards

The DVLA sends a renewal list to VOSA 2 months before a card’s expiry. This is then checked and returned to the DVLA with details of technicians whose cards can be renewed.

You must report any lost or stolen cards to VOSA and the police immediately.

If your card develops a fault or is lost or stolen, you can apply for a replacement by sending a D778B application form to VOSA. You’ll need to provide a police incident reference number for stolen cards.

Any misuse of workshop cards may lead to the withdrawal of your nominated technician and tachograph centre’s approval.
